abstract.p: Child support collections in New York reach $1 billion for 1999, 62 percent increase over record set in 1994 (S)

block.p: As of Dec. 21, child support collections for 1999 reached $1 billion, a 62 percent increase over the $617 million collected by the state in 1994. The previous annual record was set last year when $933 million was collected, Gov. George E. Pataki's office said.

As of Dec. 21, child support collections for 1999 reached $1 billion, a 62 percent increase over the $617 million collected by the state in 1994. The previous annual record was set last year when $933 million was collected, Gov. George E. Pataki's office said.

The latest figures follow a series of successes attributed to the state's child support enforcement program, which has been able to suspend the driver's license of absent parents who owe more than four months in child support. Since 1995 when the law took effect, more than $4.8 billion in support payments have been collected.

More than 300,000 people have made a payment since being notified of impending suspension of their licenses. Additionally, a program with the state's Office of Taxation and Finance to make collections has resulted in receipts that averaged just under $1 million a week last year.
Collections have increased by an average of 10.6 percent each year since 1994, while the number of people paying child support increased by an average of 7.6 percent a year.
